# Greek-Gods-and-Goddess
# A simple webpage on Greek gods and goddess
# Its purpose is to inform and entertain the reader on Greek Gods, Goddess, and myths
<html>
<title>Greek Gods and Goddesses</title>
<body style="background-color:#f9edd1;">
<h1 align="center", style="color:#48764b;">Greek Gods and Goddesses</h1>
<h4 align="center", style="color:#48764b;">There are over 3000 Greek gods and goddesses. If you like the idea of myths and stories being the reason things are the way they are, then Greek mythology is a thing for you! You don't have to believe it, but it's fun to learn about it. Today we'll go over 5 greek gods/goddesses in no particular order except for the fact that we  will alternate from goddess to a god, then back to a goddess. Let's get started!</h4>
<h3 align="center" style="color:#48764b;"><br><br>Persephone</h3>
<p align="center"><img  src="data:image/jpeg;base64," alt="Greek Goddess Persephone" style="width:160px;height:316px;"></p>
<p style="color:#48764b;">Persephone is the Greek Goddess of Spring due to her mother being Demeter, the Greek Goddess of The Harvest. One afternoon, Hades asked, some say abducted, Persephone and took her to the underworld where she would soon become his wife because of a deal Zues made with Hades. Demeter was furious and wanted her daughter back. By threatening to not harvest any more food, causing mankind to soon die out, Demeter made a deal with Zeus and Hades that let Persephone free from the underworld and back to earth for 2/4rds of the year. For every time Persephone came back, the world flourished from her and Demeter. But everytime she had to return to the underworld, the earth became cold resulting in the changing of seasons! Persephone is the goddess of spring, and after marrying Hades, she also became the Goddess of Reincarnation and Ghosts.</p>

<h3 align="center", style="color:#48764b;"><br><br>Apollo</h3>
<p align="center"><img src="data:image/jpeg;base64," alt= "Greek God Apollo" style="width:140px;height:215px"></p>
<p style="color:#48764b;" >Apollo is mostly known for being the Greek God of The Sun and Light but he is also the God of Music, Poetry, Art, Prophecy, Truth, Archery, Plague, Healing, and more. Apollo had bright blonde hair that resembled the sun. Apollo's mother was Leto, Goddess of Motherhood. Apollo had a twin sister named Artemis. Hera was angered by the birth of Apollo and Artemis, because the father of Leto's children was Zeus, God of Thunder/Lightning/Rain/Winds, which was Hera's husband. Hera sent an enormous serpent to devour Leto and her children. While Apollo and Artemis grew up, Zeus gave them powerful bows. When Apollo grew up he wanted to slay the serpent that tormented his mother for so long. When he got to the cave he shot arrows at the beast but they seemed to do nothing. Apollo then shot two arrows at the same time one hitting the serpent in the eye and the other hitting its heart. Apollo shot one last arrow in the mouth of the serpent, killing it. Apollo then said that a temple would be built there in honor, this place soon became the Oracle of Delphi.</p>

<h3 align="center" style="color:#48764b;"><br><br>Aphrodite</h3>
<p align="center"><img  src="data:image/jpeg;base64," alt="Greek Goddess Aphrodite" style="width:157px;height:235px;"></p>
<p style="color:#48764b;"> Aphrodite is the Greek Goddess of Love and Beauty. Aphrodite is the daughter of Zeus and Dione, referred to as an Earth Goddess and also the Love Goddess.  Aphrodite has had many partners in love, some being Hephaestus-God of Fire who she cheated on many times with Aries, Adonis-a handsome mortal, and Anchises-a Trojan prince. Some say she was born from the white foam of the sea, and when she walked soft patches of grass trailed after her. When she walked out of the sea she was the most beautiful woman in the world and the place became the most beautiful place in the world, which is the island, Cyprus. Others say she was born from a shell Neuritis, Demi-god of Shellfish, accompanied Aphrodite before she came out from the foam of the sea. However, he didn't wish to follow her on Earth, so she turned him into a shell.</p>

<h3 align="center", style="color:#48764b;"><br><br>Hades</h3>
<p align="center"><img src="data:image/jpeg;base64," alt="Greek God Hades" style="width:132px;height:207px" ></p>
<p style="color:#48764b;"> Hades was the Greek God of the Underworld. Hades was the first born of Rhea and Cronus. Hades was the brother to Zeus, Hera, Demeter, Hestia-Goddess of Hearth/Home/Hospitality, and Poseidon-God of the Sea/Waters/Horses/Earthquakes. Hades was the caretaker of the souls, he kept them from returning back to the living. He rides a chariot drawn by four black horses. Allegedly, no one returns from going to the underworld but many myths like Orpeus and Eurydice. He has a three headed guard dog named Cerberus. Hades gets a bad reputation due to the fact that people associate the underworld and him with the devil although he is shadowy, stern, and enforces rules strictly, he has some empathy. And he also cares very deeply and is faithful to his wife, Persepone, which is quite rare in Greek mythology. When Persephone is not there in the underworld, he would usually just spend his days waiting for the time when she comes back. </p>

<h3  align="center" style="color:#48764b;"><br><br>Hera</h3>
<p align="center"><img  src="data:image/jpeg;base64," alt="Greek Goddess Hera" style="width:140px;height:215px;"></p>
<p style="color:#48764b;"> Hera is the Greek Goddess of Marriage, Women and Family, and Protector of Women during Childbirth. She is the sister and wife to Zeus. Hera seems to have many problems with jealousy. An example of this is once in her jealous rage, she turned a female nymph named Echo into what an echo is today. Echo was no longer able to tell stories but to only repeat the last thing someone else said. Terribly saddened she ran to a cave where she withered away into only a voice. You can still hear her calling back. Hera is usually angered by Zeus because is very unfaithful and doesn't try to hide it, even though Zeus flagrantly tricked her into marrying him. Hera was vain, wrathful, and short tempered. She could mind control people, alter the weather with clear skies or storms, shapeshift, and turn mortals into animals or even monsters. </p>
